definitions.definition: a small round area that has a different colour or feels different from the surface it is on

examples.text: Which has spots, the leopard or the tiger?
The male bird has a red spot on its beak.
She was wearing a black skirt with white spots.

definitions.definition: a small mark or lump on a person’s skin, sometimes with a yellow head to it

examples.text: The baby's whole body was covered in small red spots.
He had a large spot on his nose.
The aim of acne treatments is to shorten the length of time someone has spots.
teenagers worried about their spots
The children all had measles, and had broken out in spots.
enlarged pores and spots on the skin

definitions.definition: a small dirty mark on something

examples.text: His jacket was covered with spots of mud.
rust spots
There were grease spots all over the walls.

definitions.definition: a particular area or place

examples.text: a quiet/secluded/lonely spot
This is a favourite spot for walkers and climbers.
I won't drive around for 20 minutes looking for a **parking spot**.
He was exhausted and just wanted to **find a spot** to sleep.
The bay has become a popular spot for young international travellers.
He showed me the exact spot where he had asked her to marry him.
a tourist spot
She placed the ball on the penalty spot and waited for the whistle.
He stood rooted to the spot, unable to move.
It's a beautiful spot to relax and enjoy the peaceful surroundings.
On your map, X marks the spot where the race begins.
She pointed to a spot on the map.
Take the time to find the right spot to pitch your tent.
a favourite spot for picnickers
There are miles of footpaths and plenty of secluded spots.
He pointed to a spot in the western sky.
They picked a good spot for a picnic.
I was sitting in my usual spot.

definitions.definition: a small feature or part of somebody/something with a particular quality

examples.text: He usually wears a hat to hide his bald spot.
Try to identify the **weak spots** in your performance.
From her angry reply it was obvious that I had touched a sensitive spot.

definitions.definition: a small amount of something

examples.text: He's in a spot of trouble.
Would you like a spot of lunch?
She’s gone out to do a spot of shopping.
We got into a spot of bother with the police.

definitions.definition: a small amount of a liquid

examples.text: I felt a few spots of rain.
There was a spot of rain in the afternoon, but otherwise the weather has been perfect.

definitions.definition: a part of a television, radio, club or theatre show that is given to a particular person or type of entertainment

examples.text: a **guest/solo spot**

definitions.definition: a position in a competition, event or team

examples.text: two teams battling for (the) **top spot**
She has earned a spot on the national team.
Glamorgan claimed the top spot in the League.
The Korean team secured two qualifying spots for the Olympic Games.
That leaves one roster spot, and the team will need a versatile player to fill it.
The album quickly reached the number-one spot in the charts.

definitions.definition: a spotlight (= a light with a single, very bright beam that can be directed at a particular place or person, especially a performer on the stage)
a good or pleasant part of something that is unpleasant or bad in all other ways

examples.text: The win last week was the only bright spot in their last ten games.
The birth of my son was the one bright spot in a terrible year.

definitions.definition: not able to move, for example because you are frightened or surprised

examples.text: I stood rooted to the spot with terror.

definitions.definition: to like somebody/something

examples.text: She's always had a soft spot for you.

definitions.definition: if something hits the spot it does exactly what it should do
in a difficult situation

examples.text: She’ll always help you if you’re in a spot.
This could put the banks in a tight spot.
The captain's knee injury leaves the team in a tight corner.

definitions.definition: to be very much better than somebody/something

examples.text: She knocks spots off all the other candidates.

definitions.definition: people cannot change their character, especially if they have a bad character

examples.text: You didn’t really expect her to be on time, did you? A leopard can’t change its spots.

definitions.definition: immediately

examples.text: He answered the question on the spot.
an on-the-spot parking fine

definitions.definition: at the actual place where something is happening

examples.text: An ambulance was on the spot within minutes.
an on-the-spot report

definitions.definition: in one exact place, without moving in any direction

examples.text: Running on the spot is good exercise.

definitions.definition: to make somebody feel uncomfortable or embarrassed by asking them a difficult question

examples.text: The interviewer's questions really put him on the spot.

wordOrigin: Middle English: perhaps from Middle Dutch spotte. The sense ‘notice, recognize’ arose from the early 19th-cent. slang use ‘note as a suspect or criminal’.
